Models, Hypotheses and Loss Functions¶

These notes seek to establish a precise notion of losses and functions in statistical learning using a probabilistic framework

Models and Hypotheses¶

Definition

A generative model is a space \(\mathcal{M}\), along with a map:

\[\begin{split}\mathcal{M} &\overset{\Theta}\longrightarrow \mathrm{Prob}(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y}) \\ f &\longmapsto \rho^f\end{split}\]

Definition

We call \(\mathrm{Prob}(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y})\) the space of generative hypotheses

Definition

A discriminative model is a space \(\mathcal{M}\), along with a map:

\[\begin{split}\mathcal{M} &\overset{\Theta}\longrightarrow \mathrm{Maps}\bigl(\mathcal{X}, \mathrm{Prob}(\mathcal{Y})\bigl) \\ f &\longmapsto \Bigl[x \longmapsto \rho^f_x \Bigl]\end{split}\]

Definition

We call \(\mathrm{Maps}\bigl(\mathcal{X}, \mathrm{Prob}(\mathcal{Y})\bigl)\) the space of discriminative hypotheses

Loss Functions¶

A loss function pairs data and models, producing a number. This both assesses models given data and allows data to act on the space of models via gradient descents.

Definition

A loss function is a map.

\[\begin{split}\mathrm{Prob}^\mathrm{fin}(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y})\times \mathcal{M} &\overset{\mathscr{L}}\longrightarrow \mathbb{R} \\ (\rho^\mathrm{emp}, f) &\longmapsto \mathscr{L}_{\rho^\mathrm{emp}} (f)\end{split}\]

where we are viewing data, \(\rho^\mathrm{emp}\), as a finitely support probability distribution on \(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y}\)

Example

A standard example is the relative entropy:

\[\begin{split}\mathrm{Prob}^\mathrm{fin}(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y})\times \mathcal{M} \overset{\mathrm{Id} \times \Theta}\longrightarrow \mathrm{Prob}^\mathrm{fin}&(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y}) \times \mathrm{Prob}(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y})\overset{\mathcal{S}( - || - )}\longrightarrow \mathbb{R} \\ (\rho^\mathrm{emp}, f) &\longmapsto \mathcal{S}(\rho^\mathrm{emp} || \rho^f)\end{split}\]

Note

Although relative entropy does not coicide with cross entropy, they differ by a term independent of the model, so that optimizing relative entropy coincides with optimizing cross entropy

Example

RMSE

Note

Note all loss functions factor through \(\Theta\).

In many instances, there are additional regularization terms and hyperparameters

\[\begin{split}\mathcal{M} \times \Lambda &\overset{\Omega}\longrightarrow \mathbb{R} \\ f, \lambda &\longmapsto \Omega_\lambda(f)\end{split}\]
